One thing I thought about when I read the paper was, what would 
happen if =
the CPPN generates the connectivity patterns depending on 
the relative pos=
itions of each individual in realtime while on the 
field? It would require=
 a great deal of computation time (it has to 
rebuild the phenotype once pe=
r timestep per individual) but it may 
show interesting results. 

Peter

-=
-- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Dav=
id D'Ambrosio and I discuss the potential for HyperNEAT 
> controlling mult=
iple heterogeneous agents in this new 
> paper, "Generative Encoding for Mu=
ltiagent Learning," to appear at 
> GECCO 2008:
> 
> http://eplex.cs.ucf.ed=
u/index.php?
> option=3Dcom_content&task=3Dview&id=3D14&Itemid=3D28#dambros=
io.gecco08
> 
> Direct Link:
> 
> http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/dambrosio_=
gecco08.pdf
> 
> We also have a nice sample of videos that depict various e=
volved 
> teams in action:
> 
> http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/multiagenthyperneat=

> 
> The interesting idea in this paper is that just as a single 
> connec=
tive CPPN can encode how a single network varies over space, 
> it can also=
 encode how a *set* of networks (each representing the 
> policy of one age=
nt on the team) varies over space.  In this way, 
> HyperNEAT can learn an =
expression that encodes how policies vary 
> over the team geometry.  For e=
xample, in a soccer team agents vary 
> from defensive to offensive as you =
move away from the goal.  Part 
of 
> the power of this approach is that it=
 means basic skills can be 
> learned and shared among the whole team, sinc=
e the CPPN encodes how 
> those skills vary across the field.
> 
> ken
>
